metadata.case_name: Rice Millers (Appellants in C.As. 1026-1031, 902-905 of 1963) v. Deputy Director Food, Vijayawada (Respondent)
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeals No. 1026 to 1031, 902 to 905 of 1963

facts.text: On June 6, 1957, Central Government issued notification under s. 3(3A) of Essential Commodities Act, 1955, directing price regulation of rice and paddy in Andhra Pradesh inter alia to control rise in prices and prevent hoarding, for three months.

On July 31, 1957, Central Government notified that powers under s.3 (clauses f, h, i, j relating to f) for rice/paddy stocks in Andhra Pradesh exercisable by Shri K.S. Krishnan, Deputy Director Food, Vijayawada, for three months.
On July 31, 1957, Central Government authorised Shri Krishnan under cl.(iv) of sub-s.(3A) of s.3 to determine average market rate of rice/paddy in Andhra Pradesh.

On August 20, 1957, Shri Krishnan directed rice millers in Tadepalligudem to sell specified rice quantities to Assistant Director Food at prices under cls.(iii) and (iv) of sub-s.(3A) of s.3; deliveries up to September 13, 1957.
Prices for rice procured August 20 to September 13, 1957 fixed by Shri Krishnan in September 1957 under s.3(3A)(iii)(c) read with (iv); appellants dispute proper fixation.
On September 14, 1957, Central Government fixed maximum prices for rice/paddy sales over 10 maunds in Krishna, West Godavari, East Godavari districts under cl.(c) sub-s.(2) s.3.

Between September 14, 1957 and December 29, 1957, Deputy Director requisitioned rice from appellants under cl.(f) sub-s.(2) s.3, paid maximum prices fixed September 14 notification, claimed under s.3(3A).
On December 30, 1957, after new rice crop, Central Government refixed lower maximum prices in Krishna, West Godavari, East Godavari, Guntur districts under s.3(2)(c).
After December 30, 1957, Deputy Director procured more rice from appellants, paid maximum prices per December 30 notification, claimed under s.3(3A).
Appellants filed writ petitions in Andhra Pradesh High Court challenging price fixations and notifications.
High Court dismissed writ petitions by judgment/order dated August 21, 1959, with costs; certificates granted for appeal to Supreme Court.
Deputy Director used Vijayawada published prices (80 miles from Tadepalligudem), adjusted for transport, quality (inferior rice procured); no nearer published figures available.
State Marketing Officer rates showed Tadepalligudem prices ~Rs.1.20 lower than Vijayawada for same quality.
July 31, 1964 notification treated Nallarlu, Garikulu, Akkulu rice as coarse rice same quality, but 1957 evidence showed Nallarlu/Garikulu slightly inferior to Akkulu.

legal_issues.text: Whether ss.3 and 4 of Essential Commodities Act, 1955 impose unreasonable restrictions violating Art.19(1)(f) and (g).
Whether notifications fixing maximum prices only in certain Andhra districts violate Art.14.
Whether Act violates Art.31(2) by not fixing compensation amount or principles/manner for requisitioned rice.
Whether post-December 30, 1957 procurements (including rice bought Sep14-Dec29) should be at September 14 prices, not reduced December 30 prices.

Whether prices for August 20-September 13 procurements fixed properly under s.3(3A): no prior agreement attempt (cl.iii(a)), used Vijayawada published figures instead of appellants' account books, improper adjustments.

petitioner_arguments.text: Deputy Director fixed prices arbitrarily for first period (Aug20-Sep13) without notice/opportunity, not per s.3(3A); should use average market rate at Tadepalligudem preceding notification.

Maximum price notifications (Sep14, Dec30) hit by Art.14 (only certain districts), Art.19(1)(f)(g) (unreasonable restrictions, arbitrary power), Art.31(2) (no compensation principles); entitled to market rates.
Reduced Dec30 prices should not apply to rice bought Sep14-Dec29 at higher Sep14 prices, which became minimums.
For first period, Deputy Director skipped agreement under iii(a), directly used iii(c); account books are 'published figures' as shown to tax authorities.
Vijayawada figures improper (distant); 1964 notification treats procured rice same as Akkulu used by Deputy Director.

respondent_arguments.text: Prices fixed per Act provisions; ss.3,4 and orders not hit by Arts.14,19(1)(f)(g),31(2).
Certain districts are surplus rice areas, form class; price control stabilizes others.
Post-Dec29 procurement correctly at Dec30 prices; new crop reduced market prices, normal business risk.
First period: no controlled price, so directly iii(c); Vijayawada nearest published figures, proper adjustments for distance/quality; account books not 'published'.

court_reasoning.text: ss.3,4 upheld as not violating Art.19(1)(f)(g); similar to upheld Essential Supplies Act and prior decision on this Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Too late to challenge; reasons in Harishankar Bagla and Bhanamal Gulzarimal cases apply.

court_reasoning.text: No Art.14 violation: districts are surplus rice producing, form class; controls stabilize other districts.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Orders confined to surplus districts subserve s.3(1) purpose.

court_reasoning.text: Art.31(2) satisfied: s.3(1) mandates fair prices (principle); manner in s.3(3),(3A).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Fair price involves all relevant factors; legislature indicated principle.

court_reasoning.text: Dec30 reduced prices apply to all post-Dec29 procurement, including prior stocks; new crop caused fall, normal market risk; prevents two price tiers, against s.3(1) purpose.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Analogous to free market fluctuations; appellants cannot complain.

court_reasoning.text: First period: no controlled price, so iii(c) direct; no need prior agreement (a,b only if controlled price). Vijayawada nearest published figures; adjustments proper; account books not published.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Published means generally publicised (e.g. newspapers); Deputy Director acted per iv, finality clause limits interference.

court_reasoning.text: 1964 notification does not invalidate 1957 adjustments; evidence showed quality difference; 1964 allows State discretion for varieties.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 1964 treats slight difference negligible, but 1957 evidence supports adjustment.

holdings.text: ss.3,4 of Act not hit by Art.19(1)(f)(g).
Price notifications not discriminatory under Art.14.
Act provides compensation principles/manner under Art.31(2).
First period prices fixed validly under s.3(3A)(iii)(c),(iv).

precedents_cited.case_name: Harishankar Bagla v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Uphheld ss.3,4 Essential Supplies Act, 1946 (similar to present Act)

precedents_cited.case_name: Union of India v. Bhanamal Gulzarimal
precedents_cited.relevance: Uphheld Essential Commodities Act, 1955 ss.3,4 relying on Harishankar Bagla

statutes_cited.name: Essential Commodities Act, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Authorises price controls, requisitions; mandates fair prices; manner/principles for compensation; upheld as constitutional

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: No violation by Act/orders: reasonable restrictions, no discrimination, fair price principles for acquisition

statutes_cited.name: Essential Supplies (Temporary Powers) Act, 1946
statutes_cited.relevance: Predecessor Act upheld; terms similar to present ss.3,4

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed all appeals, upholding High Court dismissal of writ petitions; all contentions rejected, prices fixed validly per Act, no constitutional violations.
outcome.costs: High Court awarded costs to respondent; Supreme Court silent

key_quotes.text: "the average market rate so determined shall be final and shall not be called in question in any Court."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: s.3(3A)(iv) limits judicial interference unless serious injustice

key_quotes.text: "The districts to which the orders applied are surplus rice producing districts... and that is why the orders were confined to those districts."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects Art.14 challenge; classifies districts reasonably

key_quotes.text: "the price fixed should be fair, and that involves in it all factors which have to be taken into account in fixing a fair price."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Art.31(2) satisfied by s.3(1) principle of fair price

key_quotes.text: "The words 'published figures' must be given their ordinary meaning... publicised in some way... in newspapers, or on the Radio."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Account books not published figures under s.3(3A)(iv)
